item.title: [SNOW] Why Asana (ASAN) Stock Is Trading Lower Today
item.description: Shares of work management platform Asana (NYSE:ASAN) fell 7.5% in the afternoon session after a wave of competitive anxiety hit the enterprise software sector sparked by a high-profile downgrade of Adobe, triggering a broader sell-off in high-valuation cloud stocks.

item.title: [GOOG] Nasdaq Is Getting a Boost From Some Big Tech Names
item.description: The Nasdaq Composite turned back around in early Tuesday afternoon trading. The Dow, which was weighed down by struggles among its larger stocks like Salesforce, Visa, and JPMorgan Chase, was down 275 points, or 0.6%. A rally in Alphabet, up 2.4%, and Nvidia, up 1.4%, helped lift the Nasdaq.

item.title: [NVDA] China limits Nvidia chip purchases to special circumstances, Information reports
item.description: The Chinese government this week told some tech companies it would only approve ​their purchases of Nvidia's H200 AI chips under special ‌circumstances, such as for university research, the Information reported on Tuesday, ‌citing two people with direct knowledge of the situation. The move signals Beijing is remaining cautious about fully reopening the Chinese market to Nvidia, whose semiconductors are pivotal in operating ⁠the most advanced ‌artificial intelligence applications and data centers. China's government issued a "deliberately vague" directive, the report said, telling ‍some technology firms to buy chips only when "necessary" but was unclear as to what that means.

item.description: AstraZeneca has agreed to buy Boston-based Modella AI, the companies said on Tuesday, as the drug industry ​increases its use of artificial intelligence to accelerate the discovery of ‌new drugs. The companies did not disclose financial terms. In a press release, Modella AI said its "foundation ‌models" and AI agents would be integrated into oncology research and development to support clinical development and biomarker discovery.

item.title: [LLOY.L] Industry sounds new alarm bell over Reeves's ISA reforms
item.description: The investment industry has intensified warnings to the government over plans to limit cash ISAs, arguing that they risk undermining British investors' willingness to back listed companies. Sky News has learnt that a meeting on Tuesday involving major industry players including Hargreaves Lansdown, HSBC and Lloyds Banking Group, along with officials from the Treasury and HM Revenue and Customs, descended into a heated exchange over the implications of the Treasury's reforms. Under plans confirmed by Rachel Reeves at November's Budget, the cash ISA allowance will be slashed from £20,000 to £12,000 from April 2027, with the exception of savers aged under 65.

item.title: [GOOG] Microsoft's Brad Smith pushes Big Tech to 'pay our way' for AI data centers amid rising opposition
item.description: It won’t be easy for Big Tech companies to win the hearts and minds of Americans who are angered about massive artificial intelligence data centers sprouting up in their neighborhoods, straining electricity grids and drawing on local reservoirs. Microsoft is trying anyway. The software giant's president, Brad Smith, is meeting with federal lawmakers Tuesday to push forward an approach that calls for the industry, not taxpayers, to pay the full costs of the vast network of computing warehouses needed to power AI chatbots like ChatGPT, Google's Gemini and Microsoft's own Copilot.

item.title: [GOOG] Tech Weekly: Apple and Google do a deal, Glasses for the Blind
item.description:
STORY: From Apple and Google doing a deal to Glasses for the Blind, this is Tech Weekly.

:: Tech Weekly

Apple and Google-owner Alphabet have done a deal.

The iPhone maker will use Google's Gemini models for its revamped Siri coming later this year.

It deepens their alliance in the AI era and boosts Alphabet's position in the race against OpenAI.

Google's technology already drives much of Samsung's Galaxy AI.

But the Siri deal unlocks a massive market with Apple's base of more than two billion active devices.

And there's no sign Apple's dominance of global smartphones has let up.

The firm led the sector with a 20% share of the market last year - just ahead of Samsung.

Leading analyst Counterpoint Research said the firm saw solid demand in emerging and mid-sized markets.

And enjoyed strong sales of the iPhone 17 series.

The latest innovations in the tech sector were on show at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas.

.lumen showed off its so-called Glasses for the Blind.

The device goes on a person's head and acts in a similar way to a guide dog.

The firm said the glasses use haptics to help people with blindness go about daily life.

And employs AI to distinguish between safe and unsafe surfaces.

A new robotaxi design was unveiled in Vegas.

It's the product of a partnership between EV-maker Lucid, Uber and autonomous vehicle tech firm Nuro.

The car uses Nvidia's AI driving hardware, and can drive itself in certain conditions without a human using Nuro's autonomous tech.

David Salguero is Nuro's Head of Communications.

"We use an AI autonomy foundation model that basically learns as it goes along. So as we're driving, as we are testing, both on road and in simulations, it gets better and better at driving."

The group plans to launch robotaxi services in the San Francisco Bay Area later this year.

And AI wearables were on show in Vegas, too.

Some of the wearable tech included rings, jewelry, exoskeletons and glasses.

AI jewlery company Nirva showed products it claims can track your mood and record a journal of your day.

While tech firm ible demonstrated noise-cancelling headphones which they said can detect pollution and purify the air in front of your face.

In this episode of Stocks in Translation, The Futurum Group Daniel Newman joins host Jared Blikre and Yahoo Finance Senior Reporter Brooke DiPalma to discuss the potential $1 trillion IPOs of OpenAI and SpaceX. Newman breaks down investor hype, competitive moats, and market risks, while also exploring Google (GOOG) Gemini’s AI gains, Apple's (AAPL) innovation gap, and how Amazon (AMZN) and Meta (META) are positioned to dominate AI in 2026.Check out the full episode here. Twice a week, Stocks In Translation cuts through the market mayhem, noisy numbers and hyperbole to give you the information you need to make the right trade for your portfolio. You can find more episodes here, or watch on your favorite streaming service. This post was written by Lauren Pokedoff

item.description: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, still believes in the investment case ​for artificial intelligence in the year ahead but ‌will be focusing on broader opportunities, it said on Tuesday. Investors seeking ‌to play the AI theme into 2026 favour energy and infrastructure providers over Wall Street big tech, BlackRock said in its Investment Directions report, citing a recent investor ⁠survey it conducted. AI and ‌big tech dominated markets and world equity returns in 2025, but as the multitrillion-dollar ‍race between the likes of Microsoft, Meta and Alphabet to build new data centres generates worries about uncertain returns on capital ​and higher borrowing, investors were looking for new ‌ideas, the BlackRock survey showed.

item.title: [NVDA] Nvidia says no upfront payment needed for its H200 chips
item.description: Nvidia does not require upfront payment for H200 chips, a ​spokesperson for the U.S. chipmaker said in ‌a statement to Reuters on Tuesday. The company said it "would ‌never require customers to pay for products they do not receive", in a response to a Reuters story on January 8 about the company ⁠having imposed unusually ‌stringent terms requiring full upfront payment from Chinese customers seeking its artificial intelligence ‍chips. One source told Reuters that Nvidia's standard terms for Chinese clients have previously included advance payment requirements, ​but they were sometimes allowed to place ‌a deposit rather than make a full payment upfront.

The chipmaker said in a statement that the construction of the new factory ⁠will begin in ‌April, with completion targeted by the end of next year. SK Hynix said ‍accelerating global competition in AI is driving a sharp rise in demand for AI-focused memory, underscoring ​the need to respond proactively to growing ‌demand for high-bandwidth memory (HBM) chips.

item.title: [GOOG] Why Google's co-founders and Peter Thiel are exiting California
item.description: Big Tech elites, like Alphabet's (GOOG, GOOGL) Google co-founders Sergey Brin and Larry Page and Palantir's (PLTR) Peter Thiel, are hauling out of California to escape the state's billionaire tax act, which entails a one-time 5% tax on their wealth. If approved, the tax could affect individuals who were California residents at the year's start. Tusk Venture Partners founder and CEO Bradley Tusk outlines what the shift out of California signals about taxation and the sociopolitical dynamics at play. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination.

item.title: [GOOG] Google's corporate parent joins $4 trillion club as investors continue to bet on AI breakthroughs
item.description: Google parent Alphabet Inc. on Monday became the fourth Big Tech powerhouse to be valued at $4 trillion, a once seemingly unfathomable milestone that's become more like a rite of passage amid an artificial intelligence arms race. Alphabet reached the threshold just four months after Google dodged the U.S. government's attempt to break up its internet empire following a ruling last year that branded its ubiquitous search engine an illegal monopoly. In an effort to prevent further abuses, a federal judge overseeing the case ordered a shake-up that investors widely interpreted as a slap on the wrist, resulting in a 57% increase in Alphabet's stock price since then that has created an additional $1.4 trillion in shareholder wealth.

item.title: [GOOG] Can We Retire at 62 With $690K In A Roth IRA, $1,800 In Social Security, And No Mortgage — But $500 A Month In Out-of-Pocket Medical Costs?
item.description: Retiring at 62 sounds doable when the house is paid off and there's a solid nest egg waiting. But for one Florida couple, even a well-prepped plan feels like it's riding a tightrope. Together, they've saved $690,000 in a Roth IRA and expect $1,800 a month in combined Social Security benefits. Their mortgage is gone, which lifts a major weight. But their biggest concern heading into retirement isn't housing — it's healthcare. They're budgeting $500 a month out-of-pocket for Medicare premiums, pre

item.title: [LLY0.F] Nvidia Stock Closes Flat. The Chip Maker Is Launching an AI Lab with Eli Lilly.
item.description: Nvidia stock was languishing Monday despite news of a partnership with pharmaceutical company Eli Lilly The chip company’s investors remain focused progress on sales in China and the health of the wider artificial-intelligence sector. The stock is down 1.8% over the past month, as a flurry of robotics and autonomous-driving related announcements at the CES trade show, formerly known as the Consumer Electronics Show, failed to provide a boost. Nvidia said Monday that it was joining with Eli Lilly to fund an AI lab with an investment of up to $1 billion over five years to build models for biology and chemistry.

item.title: [LLY0.F] Expect a Busy Year in Obesity Drugs as New Pills Hit the Market
item.description: Pill versions of the successful GLP1 drugs from Novo Nordisk and Eli Lilly will likely be on the market in 2026’s first half.

item.title: [GOOG] Meta plans to cut around 10% of employees in Reality Labs division, NYT reports
item.description: Meta plans to cut around 10% of the employees in its Reality Labs division who ​work on products including the metaverse, the New York ‌Times reported on Monday, citing three people with knowledge of the discussions. The cuts ‌to Reality Labs, which has roughly 15,000 employees, could be announced as soon as Tuesday and are set to disproportionately affect those in the metaverse unit who work on virtual reality ⁠headsets and virtual social ‌networks, the report said. The metaverse had been a massive project spearheaded by CEO Mark Zuckerberg, who prioritized and ‍spent heavily on the venture, only for the business to burn more than $60 billion since 2020.

item.title: [LLY0.F] Top Stock Reports for Microsoft, Eli Lilly & Lam Research
item.description: Microsoft beat software peers as Azure's 25% cloud share and OpenAI-led AI lift cash flow, despite competition, regulation and rising AI capex.
